claims.text: China's debt cycle will inevitably lead to economic decline, following historical patterns of reserve currency transitions.
Manufacturing process knowledge in 'hard tech' creates durable competitive advantages that financial metrics systematically undervalue.
EUV lithography export restrictions create a hard constraint on China's semiconductor advancement that neither debt cycles nor manufacturing prowess can overcome.
BYD and CATL's rapid advancement demonstrates that manufacturing density accelerates iteration faster than capital allocation alone.

tensions.name: Determinism of decline
tensions.description: Dalio sees financial flows as deterministic of national trajectory. Wang sees manufacturing capability as potentially overriding financial headwinds. These frameworks cannot both be correct as predictive models.
tensions.stakes: Investment allocation between Chinese and Western industrial companies over 10-year horizon.

tensions.name: Sector transferability
tensions.description: Wang's evidence of rapid EV/battery advancement may not transfer to semiconductors due to unique capital requirements and export restrictions on enabling equipment.
tensions.stakes: Whether to treat China's tech sector as monolithic or segment-specific.

passes.summary: Explored three source documents. Identified 4 major claims with supporting evidence. Surfaced assumption that manufacturing and financial frameworks are competing explanations.
Distilled to core tension: debt-cycle determinism vs manufacturing-capability thesis. ASML constraint identified as potential falsification test for Wang's framework.

Applied inversion and base rates. Historical cases (Japan, Korea) show manufacturing can outrun debt concerns for decades. However, no precedent for hard technology lockout at China's scale. Two tensions surfaced, both unresolved.
